summary: NVIDIA reported an exceptional second quarter for fiscal 2024, achieving record revenue of $13.51 billion, which represents an 88% sequential increase and a 101% year-on-year growth, surpassing the expected $11 billion. The Data Center segment was a significant driver of this growth, with revenue reaching $10.32 billion, up 141% sequentially and 171% year-on-year, fueled by strong demand from cloud service providers and large internet companies for generative AI solutions. Strategic initiatives include the expansion of their AI Enterprise software stack and partnerships in the automotive sector, which are progressing well. Market conditions remain favorable, with strong demand visibility extending into the next year, although there are challenges related to overall automotive demand, particularly in China. Notable product updates include the introduction of new desktop workstation GPUs and the upcoming L40S GPU to meet diverse workload demands. Risks highlighted include potential uncertainties in market conditions and the need to manage supply chain complexities as demand continues to grow.
key_highlights: Record Q2 revenue of $13.51 billion, up 88% sequentially and 101% year-on-year.
Data Center revenue reached $10.32 billion, driven by demand for generative AI and large language models.
Strong demand visibility extends into next year, with expectations for continued growth.
Introduction of new desktop workstation GPUs and the upcoming L40S GPU to address diverse workloads.
Challenges include lower automotive demand, particularly in China, and supply chain management.

kpis.name: Total Revenue
kpis.context: Record Q2 revenue was up 88% sequentially and up 101% year-on-year.

kpis.name: Data Center Revenue
kpis.context: Record revenue for Data Center was up 141% sequentially and up 171% year-on-year.

kpis.name: Gaming Revenue
kpis.context: Gaming revenue was up 11% sequentially and 22% year-on-year.

kpis.name: GAAP Gross Margin
kpis.context: GAAP gross margins expanded to 70.1% driven by higher data center sales.

kpis.name: Non-GAAP Gross Margin
kpis.context: Non-GAAP gross margin was 71.2% driven by higher data center sales.

kpis.name: Operating Expenses (GAAP)
kpis.context: GAAP operating expenses are expected to be approximately $2.95 billion.

kpis.name: Operating Expenses (Non-GAAP)
kpis.context: Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to be approximately $2 billion.

kpis.name: Expected Q3 Revenue
kpis.context: Total revenue for Q3 is expected to be $16 billion, plus or minus 2%.

kpis.name: Installed Base Upgrade Opportunity
kpis.context: 47% of the installed base have upgraded to RTX.

kpis.name: AI Enterprise Software Revenue
kpis.context: NVIDIA's standalone software business continues to grow, with AI Enterprise included in many products.

risk_factors.description: The forward-looking statements made during the call are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and actual results may differ materially.
Demand for NVIDIA's products, particularly in the Data Center segment, may vary and impact revenue visibility.
Supply over the next several quarters may be affected by cycle times and capacity issues with supply partners.
Changes in laws and regulations could impact NVIDIA's operations and financial results.

strategic_initiatives.progress: AI Enterprise is being included with many products such as DGX and H100.
strategic_initiatives.impact: Expected to drive significant revenue growth in the software business.

strategic_initiatives.progress: Announced new APIs including RunUSD and ChatUSD to enhance generative AI capabilities.
strategic_initiatives.impact: Aims to accelerate OpenUSD's development and adoption.

strategic_initiatives.progress: Partnership with MediaTek announced to develop automotive SoCs and integrate NVIDIA's GPU chiplet.
strategic_initiatives.impact: Expected to enhance in-car experiences across various vehicle segments.
